conversation:
Shadowheart: This again? You're persistent, I'll give you that.
Shadowheart: It's nothing. Really.
Player: Tell me what you're hiding, or else.
: True
Shadowheart: Fine, I'll tell you, so long as it spares me your ham-fisted threats.
Shadowheart: You're not going to let this go, are you? You might wish you had...
Shadowheart: I worship Shar, the Mistress of the Night. It is my holy mission to oppose Selûne, her teachings and her followers.
Shadowheart: Ngh... it hurts...
Shadowheart: Don't make a fuss, Selûnite - we may be at odds, but I have more important concerns than you right now.
Shadowheart: Now that you have the truth, please don't make a big fuss about it.
Player: Shar is an abomination. You deceived me.
Shadowheart: Your blindness as much as my deception, Selûnite. We can talk about this later - if you're willing.
Shadowheart: Then it's your own fault for not asking.
Player: Now that the truth's out, tell me more.
Shadowheart: All right. As I said, Shar is my patron, my mistress. Goddess of darkness and loss.
Shadowheart: I assume you've heard of her?
Player: She doesn't sound very appealing, going by her titles.
Shadowheart: The night brings comfort. Through loss, we find acceptance. In the arms of the Dark Mother we find peace.
Player: I don't quite understand.
Shadowheart: Most fear the dark, like children, because in darkness they see their fears reflected.
Shadowheart: But Shar teaches us to step beyond fear. Beyond loss. In darkness we do not hide - we act.
Shadowheart: Pain. Hope. The promise of better days. All of these are heavy cloaks that bend our backs and burden our hearts.
Shadowheart: We shed those cloaks. Before Shar we stand gloriously naked, beyond the vanities of mortals.
Player: When you put it like that, it seems strangely comforting.

Player: That diary we found in Moonhaven - it meant something to you, I know it.

Shadowheart: Fine, I'll tell you, so long as it spares me your ham-fisted threats.
Shadowheart: You're not going to let this go, are you? You might wish you had...
Shadowheart: I worship Shar, the Mistress of the Night. It is my holy mission to oppose Selûne, her teachings and her followers.
Shadowheart: Ngh... it hurts...
Shadowheart: Now that you have the truth, please don't make a big fuss about it.
Player: I bow to Shar also. The Dark Lady must favour us, to have brought us together.

Shadowheart: Then it's your own fault for not asking.
Player: Now that the truth's out, tell me more.
Shadowheart: All right. As I said, Shar is my patron, my mistress. Goddess of darkness and loss.
Shadowheart: I assume you've heard of her?
Player: She doesn't sound very appealing, going by her titles.
Shadowheart: The night brings comfort. Through loss, we find acceptance. In the arms of the Dark Mother we find peace.
Player: There has to be something more that draws people to Shar.
Shadowheart: Most fear the dark, like children, because in darkness they see their fears reflected.
Shadowheart: But Shar teaches us to step beyond fear. Beyond loss. In darkness we do not hide - we act.
Shadowheart: Pain. Hope. The promise of better days. All of these are heavy cloaks that bend our backs and burden our hearts.
Shadowheart: We shed those cloaks. Before Shar we stand gloriously naked, beyond the vanities of mortals.
Player: Sounds... daunting. I don't think it's for me.
Shadowheart: Give it time - and thought.
Shadowheart: We tear down the lies the world is drunk on: the institutions they trust, the so-called gods they worship. The lives they cling to.
Shadowheart: We destroy false idols, topple corrupt organisations, fight heretics wherever they're found.
Shadowheart: There's often suffering - death even. Many people break before they embrace Shar's truths.

conversation:
Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you?
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Perhaps not. Patience is important, but cannot impede the other virtues.
Havkelaag: Then we are in accord - the time for action is now.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: And what if your experiment fails?
Havkelaag: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Player: Sell the egg.

Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?

conversation:
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.

Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?

Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: That kind of indoctrination and time-forced nurture violates the natural order. It invalidates the whole experiment.
Havkelaag: I won't bother to argue with you. An arboreal shaman can't be expected to understand the rigorous protocols of theoretical research.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: And what if your experiment fails?
Havkelaag: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Player: Fine. Here you go.

Halsin: Pardon the viscera. One should cherish all of nature's bounty... but goblin guts are quite far down the list.
NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.
Halsin: Not only do you speak with a bear, but you free it, too? A true friend of nature - or perhaps a lunatic.
Halsin: Either way, I owe thanks. I am the druid Halsin.
Player: Glad I could be of help.
Halsin: I must admit, I didn't expect anyone would come to my aid. Who in their right mind would infiltrate a goblin infested temple. Unless...
Halsin: ...Hrrm. That look in your eyes - I've seen it before. Are you feeling all right?
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I escaped from an illithid ship after being infected. Maybe the process was interrupted.
Halsin: Perhaps... but I wouldn't want to place all my faith in blind luck.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: Tell me what you've learned about the tadpoles' origins.
Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.
Player: You seem to know a lot about this. Will you come with me to Moonrise?
Halsin: I wish I could, but there's still work I've yet to finish - blood I've yet to spill.
Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: Kagha is dead. She was swayed by Shadow Druids. I had no choice.
Halsin: Kagha... This is my fault - I was her teacher. I will mourn her when I can.
Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.
Halsin: Chaos is welcome, in doses; it helps keep balance. But this is too much - this is unnatural.
Halsin: It's too late to merely kill this horde's leadership - their forces are already marching. If you want me to help, you need to help me first.
Halsin: You must get ahead of them, muster the defences.
Player: The grove isn't my problem. I have to concentrate on saving myself.

conversation:
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: No benefit could justify you inflicting such cruelty.
Havkelaag: Rigorous experimental methods demand we do not indulge our own emotional responses in the application of discomfort to our subjects.
Havkelaag: Only by the full, uninhibited application of psionic stimuli will we have a true measure of whether the child's innate evil has been cured.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.
response:
<think>
Okay, let's break this down. The player is interacting with Havkelaag, who wants to buy a githyanki egg to conduct experiments on. The conversation reveals that Havkelaag plans to use the egg for what he considers a morally driven study, but the player ultimately sells the egg to him.

Shadowheart's personality and background are crucial here. She's a Sharran devotee, so she follows the teachings of Shar, who is associated with loss and the night. Sharrans typically believe in the inherent darkness of the world and might see such experiments as a form of necessary evil or a way to understand and control it. However, Shadowheart also has some conflicting traits, like disliking unnecessary cruelty and valuing pragmatic solutions.

In the conversation, the player sells the egg despite the obvious cruelty involved. Havkelaag's plan involves hatching the egg and subjecting it to harsh, experimental treatments. Shadowheart would likely disapprove of this because it's cruel and unnecessary, even if it's for a "noble" cause. She values efficiency and might see this as a wasteful or inhumane use of the egg. Additionally, her background with the Cloister and her own experiences with forced experiments (like the Mirror of Loss) could make her empathize with the githyanki egg's plight. 

Moreover, Shadowheart's alignment with Shar might not necessarily condone this kind of cruelty. While Sharrans do embrace darkness, they also value purpose and pragmatism. If the experiment doesn't serve a clear, strategic goal aligned with Shar's interests, she might disapprove. Also, her personal history with Rennald and the trauma from her own training could make her sensitive to such unethical experiments.

So, the player's action here is to sell the egg, leading to Havkelaag's cruel experiment. Shadowheart's disapproval would stem from the unnecessary cruelty, lack of pragmatic benefit, and the ethical violation similar to her own past. Therefore, the approval rating should be on the disapprove side, possibly even highly disapprove because it's a direct act of enabling harm without clear benefit.
</think>

conversation:
Viconia DeVir: Always a pleasure to see old acquaintances. But you would be wise to not interfere in this matter.
Player: With such an audience? A trap, if I ever saw one.
Viconia DeVir: A trap? Perhaps. But not all traps need to be sprung. Sometimes it's wiser to await an even greater prey.
Viconia DeVir: I saw in your mind, when we spoke above. Quite an adventure has brought you to this point - illithids, kidnapping, infection, the Hells, hunted by cultists and githyanki alike... and of course, the artefact.
Viconia DeVir: You have value. Quite an adventure has brought you to this point - illithids, kidnapping, infection, the Hells, hunted by cultists and githyanki alike... and of course, the artefact.
NodeContext: Ill-ih-thids
Player: I know I have value to my patron - but what you see in me I've no idea.
Viconia DeVir: Oh but I think you do - the Mapping unearthed much more than your heartform - I saw all your secrets.
Viconia DeVir: I felt Shadowheart's presence in your mind, and with it, the artefact. She succeeded in retrieving it, but then it is you who appeared, not her. Where is the artefact?
Player: Why do you even want it?
Viconia DeVir: I did not consent to questions. But I suppose you have undergone a great deal to reach this place, and anything I tell you cannot compromise me now - for you will either leave on my terms, or not at all...
Viconia DeVir: Whispers reached my ears from all corners - potential rivals of Lady Shar, all vying for the same prize. A new god, amassing the disaffected, the outcasts - those who should turn to us.
Viconia DeVir: This 'Absolute' is but an upstart; disturbing the natural order and threatening to impede the glorious return of Lady Shar's pure, endless darkness.
Viconia DeVir: I had to act. I had to strangle that foul conspiracy while it was still in the cradle.
Viconia DeVir: We learned all we could - the artefact was the one thing the Absolutists feared. The one thing they desperately wanted to keep out of their enemies' grasp. I had to have it.
Player: Shar bid you to do all of this?
Viconia DeVir: Lady Shar's concerns lie elsewhere - with another. But she is a goddess... she can afford to ignore that which does not threaten her.
Viconia DeVir: I must keep her faith alive in mortal hearts. I must defend her ways, lead her children, stop all threats. Even if I must go against her wishes, I will prove myself her most loyal servant.
Narrator: *Viconia trails off, holding your gaze with a dark, hungry look. She has staked everything on acquiring the Astral Prism.*
Viconia DeVir: I felt Shadowheart's presence in your mind, and with it, the artefact. She succeeded in retrieving it, but then it is you who appeared, not her. Where is the artefact?
Player: Somehow I'm not sure I should tell you.
Viconia DeVir: Then this will be a very short conversation. I have not assembled my forces here just to spectate.
Viconia DeVir: Humour me with a little negotiation. Perhaps we can find terms that will allow blades to remain sheathed.
Player: As far as the artefact is concerned, there's nothing to discuss.
Viconia DeVir: Reconsider. Aid me, and you can count on my support against the Absolute. Reject me, and your journey ends here.
Viconia DeVir: How about the artefact for your life? And perhaps even my support in the battles yet to come, against the Absolute?
Player: Not happening. Even if I wanted to give it to you, I can't. The artefact is bound to me. It will kill you.
: True
Viconia DeVir: My interest is defeating the Absolute. It seems you're on that path already. I will not have it said that I am unreasonable.
Viconia DeVir: Shadowheart. Surrender her to me - she has much to answer for.
Player: Let me go, and I'll bring her to you.

conversation:
Alfira: You're all right! Thank goodness, I was worried they'd got you too.
NodeContext: Relieved. Trying to be cheerful but you're upset, and just holding it together.
Player: I heard what happened - that people were taken to Moonrise.
Alfira: I keep replaying it... over and over in my head.
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Asharak was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: I'm so sorry.
Alfira: It just... it just never stops.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: What did the cultists do to the others?
Alfira: I don't know. It just... happened so quickly.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Danger is my life - there is no greater thrill for me than the hunt.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Viconia DeVir: This 'Absolute' is but an upstart; disturbing the natural order and threatening to impede the glorious return of Lady Shar's pure, endless darkness.
Viconia DeVir: I had to act. I had to strangle that foul conspiracy while it was still in the cradle.
Viconia DeVir: We learned all we could - the artefact was the one thing the Absolutists feared. The one thing they desperately wanted to keep out of their enemies' grasp. I had to have it.

conversation:
Wulbren Bongle: Good to see you. Wasn't sure you'd make it to the city. Regretting it yet?
Wulbren Bongle: I spent a lot of time thinking of worst case scenarios while I was locked in that cell you plucked me out of at Moonrise.
Wulbren Bongle: I didn't imagine anything as bad as this. The Gondians have handed Enver Gortash the means to bring about the end of liberty in Baldur's Gate.
Wulbren Bongle: And the citizens have rolled out the red carpet for their new tyrant.
Wulbren Bongle: Resistance fighters are few and far between - my Ironhands, what's left of the Harpers, and you. I hope.
Player: Gortash is a dead man - I have reasons of my own for taking him down.
Wulbren Bongle: As long as our objective is the same, the reason doesn't matter to me. We have a common enemy.
Wulbren Bongle: But neither of us gets what we want until we deal with our biggest obstacle.
Wulbren Bongle: The Steel Watch. They're a threat to you, me - and every man, woman and child in the city.
Wulbren Bongle: They act all civilised... servants of the people. But they only serve one man.
Wulbren Bongle: When he becomes Grand Duke, it will only get worse. Laws will change, freedoms will vanish, and soon you'll be accused and sentenced before you've even committed a crime.
Wulbren Bongle: And the fucking Gondians are to blame for all of it.
Player: Perhaps the Gondians were infected with a tadpole?
Wulbren Bongle: Perhaps. All the more reason to get rid of them.
Wulbren Bongle: They invented the Steel Watchers. And they're building an army of them.
Wulbren Bongle: They've always been happy to provide their technology to despots in exchange for a stipend and the freedom to work in peace.
Wulbren Bongle: They would have licked Sarevok's boots given the chance, and now they'll kiss Gortash's ring while the city screams.
Wulbren Bongle: I had a plan to put a stop to them. But the way things are now, if we stick our heads above ground, the Watchers are on us like flies on shit.
Player: What was the plan?
Wulbren Bongle: Same as it always is. Eliminate the threat.
Wulbren Bongle: In this case - the foundry where these atrocities are produced.
Wulbren Bongle: The Gondians are ingenious. But we're more than equal to them - there's nothing they can build that the Ironhands can't tear down.
Wulbren Bongle: I've built something unique for just that purpose.
Wulbren Bongle: A runepowder bomb - first of its kind. Fifty wizards high on the Weave couldn't summon this kind of firepower.
Wulbren Bongle: Get the bomb inside the Gondian facility, and - boom. Problem solved.
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren, please. This is too far! Everyone in the foundry would be killed.
Wulbren Bongle: Quiet, Barcus. The adults are talking.
Player: Those metal monsters spit in nature's face, but mass murder is a bit far.
Wulbren Bongle: It's liberation.
Wulbren Bongle: The Gondians picked their side the minute they took orders from Gortash.
Wulbren Bongle: If they had any courage, they'd have refused him and died like heroes, spitting in his face.
Wulbren Bongle: Now they'll die like the dogs they are.
Player: Gortash is the enemy - not the Gondians. I'll find another way.
response:
<think>
Okay, let's break this down. The player is interacting with Wulbren Bongle and others in the context of planning to take down Gortash's regime. The key point here is the player's response to Wulbren's plan to use a bomb on the Gondian foundry, which would kill everyone there. The player argues against it, saying that Gortash is the enemy, not the Gondians, and wants to find another way.

Shadowheart's personality is important here. She's a Sharran cleric devoted to Shar, which values pragmatism and efficiency. However, she also disapproves of unnecessary cruelty and violence. She's shown to value her goals but also has a streak of not wanting indiscriminate killing. In the conversation, Wulbren is advocating for a plan that would result in mass deaths, which Shadowheart might see as excessive. The player's refusal to go along with that plan aligns with Shadowheart's own tendencies to avoid unnecessary violence when possible. 

Additionally, Shadowheart might approve of the player's focus on targeting the real enemy (Gortash) rather than collateral damage. Even though she's ruthless, she's not mindless about it. The player's stance here shows a more measured approach, which Shadowheart would likely support. The fact that the player is looking for an alternative method that minimizes harm would resonate with her pragmatic yet somewhat humane side.

So, the approval here is likely positive. The player is avoiding a plan that would cause mass murder, which Shadowheart wouldn't support, even if the goal is to stop Gortash. Therefore, the approval category would be "Approve" or maybe even "Highly approve." But since the player is choosing a more discriminate approach, which aligns with Shadowheart's values of efficiency without unnecessary cruelty, "Approve" seems right. conversation:
Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you?
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: You're letting your personal biases affect your method. Why assume they're evil?
Havkelaag: I assume nothing. Innate githyanki cruelty is an established fact - no doubt you witnessed it yourself in the retrieval of the egg itself.
Havkelaag: When I have a suitable sample for my study, I will, however, prove that the effects of their biological inclination are reversible.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: So you're planning to torture a child for a year?
Havkelaag: The child will be a better individual after my treatment than it ever would have been had it been raised in its natural environment.
Havkelaag: Any suffering it endures will therefore be worth it, for the child, perhaps for the whole of civilised society.

: True

conversation:
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Patience does not delay, it simply tempers virtue. Curtails it from excess.
Havkelaag: A cautious, hesitant instinct. One I am afraid we do not have time for.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: This experiment is barbaric. You're never getting the egg.

NodeContext: Hint of wry humour, Introducing himself after transforming from an owlbear and killing several goblins.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Halsin raises a hand to your head, magically connecting with you (no contact). He gives an alarmed look - he knows what’s inside you
Halsin: Oak Father preserve you, child... You're infected, aren't you? The mind flayers' spawn.
Halsin: But... something's different. You're aware of the monster inside you. You don't bow to the Absolute, like the True Souls do...
Halsin: How is this possible...?
Player: I think this artefact has something to do with it.
Halsin: Hmmm... that looks very alien. As alien as the mind flayers. They do not belong on this world.
Halsin: You weren't speaking lightly when you said you needed help. Let me tell you what I know.
Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: So all of this was for nothing.

Halsin: I overheard that the cultists are sending all of their captives to Moonrise Towers.
Halsin: Innocents go in, True Souls come out. Given that all of these True Souls are infected, it has to be the source of this magic.
Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.

Halsin: I'm as certain as I can be. If you have a better alternative, I won't stop you.

Halsin: I've no right to ask more of you... but if you could help me, I'd be free to join your journey to Moonrise.
Halsin: I cannot allow these butchers to threaten my grove. The natural order must be protected.
Player: All right. How do I help?
Halsin: My thanks. If you prevail, I'll owe you the debt of a lifetime.

Halsin: They are the ones holding these parasites together. Remove them and nature will cure itself.
Player: I'll deal with this. You get to safety.
Halsin: I told you, nowhere is safe. Not while this rot festers. Once it is cut out - once the grove is secure - then I shall leave.

Halsin: Be warned - my presence could make things more difficult... I can only restrain my bear form so much. I won't be able to help but attack goblins.

Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.

Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: What lesson are you teaching these sisters?

Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.

Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.

Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.

Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.

Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?

conversation:
Havkelaag: Ah, a fellow inhabitor of the Underdark.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to our subterranean home: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: You would teach the child virtue, but rear it without patience. Curious.
Havkelaag: Tell me, then, philosopher - if patience delays the fostering of the other virtues, can it be rightly called virtuous?
Player: Patience does not delay, it simply tempers virtue. Curtails it from excess.
Havkelaag: A cautious, hesitant instinct. One I am afraid we do not have time for.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Sounds pointless. Public opinion will hardly be swayed by such a small experiment.
Havkelaag: Not at first. But if the experiment proves successful, it must be repeated. Only then will we know if the findings are to be trusted.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.

Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.

Player: You will stop this sick spectacle at once.

Astarion: He's just like Cazador - utterly insane.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.

conversation:

Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.

Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Loss.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.

Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.

Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: Why not have them hone their skills on each other?
: True
Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.

Malus Thorm: It is a proud moment when one sees one's teachings so lovingly taken to heart.
Malus Thorm: You are to be commended for their graduation - rewarded with the promised cure.

Halsin: I've been studying these parasites for a while now. Ever since I discovered these so-called True Souls are infected with them.
Halsin: Someone is using very powerful magic to modify these tadpoles. They are using them to exert control over the infected.
Halsin: I'm sorry to say, I can't undo that magic, which means I can't cure you. But that doesn't mean I can't help.
Halsin: I didn't find what I came here for - a way to remove the tadpoles - but I found the next best thing. I found out where they come from.
Halsin: That must be where these enchantments are placed on them, and it's where you'll find your cure.
Player: So all of this was for nothing.

Halsin: If you want to find a cure, you must head there and discover how the tadpoles are being manipulated.

Halsin: But there are other matters to attend to before that.

Halsin: Help me kill the leaders of this horde, save my grove. Then I will help you.

Halsin: Three deaths could win us peace: the drow Minthara, the hobgoblin Dror Ragzlin, and that perversion of a priestess, Gut.

Narrator: *In an instant, Shadowheart hides the box from view.*
Shadowheart: It's nothing, trust me. Interesting choice of camp we have here, isn't it? Peaceful.
NodeContext: Airy, deflecting.
Player: Use the parasite - see what she's hiding.
: True
Narrator: *You feel Shadowheart's deep protectiveness of the artefact. Though she doesn't understand it, she believes that her fate is entwined with it somehow.*

Shadowheart: I wish that was true. But I've seen plenty of blood spilled for just those kinds of things. The world will keep on scheming, no matter what happens to us.

Shadowheart: Thank you. We can talk again soon.

conversation:

Player: Say nothing.
Player: Use the power of the parasite. Feel inside Shadowheart's mind.
: True

Shadowheart: As you command, Nightsinger.
Shar: Now go. Warm my blade with moon-crazed blood. And be wary of your companion - they pry in your thoughts.
Shadowheart: That wasn't for you to hear.
Player: I'm sorry, I couldn't help myself.
Shadowheart: Yes, you could have. Don't pretend otherwise.
Shadowheart: There's something I need to do once we enter the Dark Lady's domain. Any more meddling on your part will end badly.
Player: Whatever you think you're going to do in there - forget it.
Player: Forget it. We're not going to sacrifice a life to Shar.
Shadowheart: You will not stand in my way. Draw your weapon.
Player: Let's calm down. We'll talk about it later.
Player: All right. Fine. Let's move on.
Shadowheart: No. Not yet. We can't go on - not without the Spear of Night. We must return to the library.
Player: I don't care about the spear - I'm continuing.
Shadowheart: My Lady does not want you to.
Shadowheart: Please. Don't make me do this - not after all we've been through.
NodeContext: Imploring someone she respects to change their mind, or she'll be forced to attack them

Shadowheart: Good. Somewhere in the library there should be an image of my Lady that we can shroud in darkness. The spear should reveal itself.
